title: 108_s1932
content: The Act may be cited as the "Artists' Rights and Theft Prevention Act of 2004" or the "ART Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that intellectual property, including music, film, and software, is crucial for innovation and economic development. These industries account for a significant portion of the US economy and employment. The No Electronic Theft (NET) Act was passed in 1997 to combat illegal reproduction and distribution of copyrighted materials. It strengthens copyright and trademark laws to prosecute individuals involved in large-scale infringement. Enforcement of copyright infringements under the NET Act is resource-intensive and poses significant challenges. The distribution of prerelease commercial works poses economic harm, with camcorders in movie theaters being a serious threat to the film industry. Online theft of music, film, and software is on the rise, negatively impacting the US economy. Federal legislation is needed to address online theft of intellectual property, which has caused a significant drop in sales for the music industry. This legislation is warranted to combat the negative economic impact on the United States economy, as outlined in Article 1, section 8 of the Constitution. The importance of intellectual property industries to the US economy is significant, with theft and unauthorized distribution occurring regularly across state and international lines. Criminal penalties for unauthorized recording of motion pictures in exhibition facilities are addressed in Section 3. Section 2319B of Title 18, US Code, criminalizes unauthorized recording of motion pictures in exhibition facilities. Offenders face imprisonment for up to 3 years, fines, or both for the first offense, and up to 6 years for subsequent offenses. When convicted of unauthorized recording of motion pictures, the court can order the forfeiture and destruction of illegal copies and equipment used in the offense. Authorized investigative activities are exempt from this section, and theaters are granted immunity under certain circumstances. The law allows the detention of individuals suspected of violating the unauthorized recording of motion pictures for questioning by law enforcement. Those involved in detaining suspects are not liable for civil or criminal actions. Victims of this offense can submit a victim impact statement during the presentence report preparation. The victim impact statement includes the identification of the victim, extent of injury and loss, and economic impact. It also involves producers, sellers, and holders of legitimate works affected by the offense. The terms 'copy', 'copyright owner', 'motion picture', 'motion picture exhibition facility', and 'transmit' are defined in section 101 of title 17. An 'audiovisual recording device' refers to any technology capable of recording or transmitting copyrighted motion pictures or audiovisual works. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 113 of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 4. Criminal infringement of a work being prepared for commercial distribution includes unauthorized recording of motion pictures in a motion picture exhibition facility. The term 'motion picture exhibition facility' is defined as a venue primarily used for exhibiting copyrighted motion pictures to the public or an assembled group outside of a family circle. Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to criminalize willful copyright infringement for commercial gain or distribution of copyrighted works exceeding $1,000 in value. This includes making works available on public computer networks. The amendment to Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code criminalizes willful copyright infringement for commercial gain or distribution of copyrighted works exceeding $1,000 in value, including making works available on public computer networks. It defines 'work being prepared for commercial distribution' as a computer program, musical work, motion picture, or sound recording with a reasonable expectation of commercial distribution at the time of unauthorized distribution. Willful infringement of a copyright cannot be solely established by evidence of reproduction or distribution of a copyrighted work. The amendment to Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code criminalizes willful copyright infringement for commercial gain or distribution of copyrighted works exceeding $1,000 in value. It includes making works available on public computer networks and defines 'work being prepared for commercial distribution' as a work with a reasonable expectation of commercial distribution at the time of unauthorized distribution. The amendment to Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code expands the scope of copyright infringement penalties. It includes imprisonment and fines for offenses related to unauthorized distribution of copyrighted works. The amendment to Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code increases penalties for copyright infringement, including imprisonment and fines for offenses committed for commercial advantage or financial gain, second or subsequent offenses, and unauthorized distribution of copyrighted works. The term 'financial gain' is defined in section 101 of title 17, while 'work being prepared for commercial distribution' is defined in section 506(a) of title 17. Civil remedies are available for infringement of a work being prepared for commercial distribution. Preregistration of works being prepared for commercial distribution is allowed under new regulations issued by the Register of Copyrights. This applies to works with a history of infringement before authorized commercial distribution. Applicants must submit an application to the Copyright Office within 3 months of the work's first publication. The Copyright Office requires submission of an application, deposit, and fee for registration of a work. Failure to submit these items within 3 months of first publication or 1 month of learning of infringement will result in dismissal of infringement actions. Preregistration is allowed for works preparing for commercial distribution to address infringement issues. The Copyright Office allows preregistration for works to address infringement issues. Section 412 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include preregistration for copyright infringement actions. The Federal Sentencing Guidelines are addressed in Section 6. The United States Sentencing Commission must review and potentially amend sentencing guidelines for intellectual property crimes within 180 days of this Act. They have the authority to make amendments following specific procedures. The United States Sentencing Commission is responsible for ensuring that sentencing guidelines for intellectual property crimes are stringent and reflective of the nature of the offenses. They will consider providing sentencing enhancements for unauthorized display, performance, publication, reproduction, or distribution of copyrighted works. Additionally, they will assess the scope of "uploading" in relation to these crimes. The United States Sentencing Commission will assess if the sentencing guidelines adequately address losses from broad distribution of copyrighted works online and reflect harm to victims from copyright infringement when reproduction or distribution frequency is unknown. Authorization of appropriations to the Department of Justice for prosecuting violations of intellectual property rights under specific sections of the United States Code. $5,000,000 allocated for each fiscal year from 2005 to 2009.
